description: From Middle English savacioun, from Old French savaciun, salvaciun, from Latin salvātiō. Displaced native Old English hǣlu.

entries.meaning: (religion) The process of being saved, the state of having been saved (from hell).
examples: Collective salvation is not possible without personal salvation, but the latter is achievable.

entries.meaning: The process of being restored or made new for the purpose of becoming saved; the process of being rid of the old poor quality conditions and becoming improved.

verbs.description: salvation (third-person singular simple present salvations, present participle salvationing, simple past and past participle salvationed)

entries.meaning: (rare) To save, in the religious sense; to bring to salvation.
